intro: Paepalanthus parviflorus, commonly known as the small-flowered puya, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in the Andean regions of Peru and Bolivia. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae, which is closely related to the grass family. The plant is characterized by its rosette of narrow, sword-shaped leaves and produces small, clustered inflorescences with pale yellow to greenish flowers. It is adapted to high-altitude environments and is often found in rocky or dry habitats. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
